0.14.text: Anyone who lives alone and manifests no longing to be in a relationship

4.86.text: is in our times, almost automatically, more or less secretly

8.52.text: viewed as both pitiable and deeply troubled.

11.46.text: It's simply not thought possible to be at once, alone and normal.

16.30.text: This sets up for collective catastrophe,

19.02.text: because it means that a huge number of people,

21.36.text: who have no innate wish to live with anyone else,

24.14.text: and are thought deeply ill-suited to doing so

27.16.text: are every year press ganged and shamed into conjugal life

31.50.text: with disastrous results for all involved.

34.38.text: Only once singlehood has completely equal prestige with its alternative

38.84.text: can we ensure that people will be free in their choices

42.08.text: and hence join couples for the right reasons; because they love another person,

47.74.text: rather than because they are terrified of remaining single.

52.08.text: Here, then, are a few of the many good reasons to spend your life alone:

57.96.text: 1. Because romantic love is a dangerous illusion.

61.18.text: We should recognize that romantic love

63.82.text: the idea of being deeply enamored of one special partner over a whole lifetime,

69.32.text: is a very new, ambitious and really pretty odd concept, at best 250 years old.

74.44.text: From close-up, over long periods of time,

77.16.text: almost everyone is condemned to be pretty dispiriting and difficult

81.60.text: A good Romantic marriage is evidently theoretically possible,

85.60.text: but it's also be extremely unlikely in practice,

89.06.text: which should make any failure feel a good deal less shameful.

94.06.text: 2. No one thinks their partner is terrific - After a while.

97.74.text: Those among us who chose to stay single should not be thought un-Romantic.

102.50.text: Indeed, we may be among the very most Romantic of all,

105.76.text: because it is in the end the fervent Romantics

108.58.text: who should be especially careful of ending up in mediocre relationships:

113.12.text: relationships best suit the kind of people

116.00.text: who don’t actually expect too much from them.

119.34.text: 3. We aren't sane enough to be in relationships.

122.54.text: Though it is a sign of some maturity to know how to love and live alongside someone,

127.20.text: it it is actually a sign of even greater maturity

130.40.text: to recognise that this is something one isn’t in the end

133.72.text: going to be psychologically capable of – as a good portion of us simply are not.

141.38.text: in order to save others (and oneself)

143.70.text: from the consequences of one’s own inner emotional turmoil

148.42.text: is the true sign of a great and kind soul.

152.10.text: 4. Being alone means not inflicting yourself on others.

155.86.text: It spares you from constant reminders of how difficult and strange you are.

160.44.text: No one is there to hold a mirror up – record your antics

163.96.text: and constantly make you accountable for them.

166.24.text: If you’re lucky, you will be able to tolerate and even like yourself if you are on your own.

175.56.text: It may be better to feel alone and be denied sex outside of a relationship

181.88.text: One thing the single are never denied,

185.80.text: All this isn’t to say that being alone is without problems.

189.62.text: There are of course drawbacks to both states,

192.40.text: being single and being in a couple:

196.18.text: suffocation, anger and frustration in the other.

199.46.text: The truth is, we’re simply not terribly good at being happy whatever our relationship status.

204.78.text: Which is ultimately an argument for neither rushing too fast into a couple,

210.46.text: or rushing too fast out of one.
